title: Tuesday, 31st January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

PM11:01am

11:11 am

Ocado

PM11:11am

11:11 am

2016 is in line.

PM11:11am

Finals here http://www.investe...1701310700095302V/

BE11:12am

Which is good because the forecasts had been lowballed going into this.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Today's Rocket is a rally rather than a ..... whatever, soar, thingmy.

BE11:13am

There's no news of course. No international deal (news on which would never be held back to match the timing of results anyway, of course, clearly).

BE11:13am

There's a flag of capex increasing, which isn't surprising because Ocado's growth is extremely capex hungry.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

For as long as it's a growth stock it's also an unprofitable one. That's the catch 22 with Ocado.

BE11:15am

Let me get Goldman. Ocado's pet broker.

BE11:15am

Sorry, house. Not pet. House.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Ocado reported FY16 Group sales growth of +14.8% yoy to £1.27 bn, in line with GSe and Bloomberg consensus with Ocado.com sales growing +13.3% to £1.17 bn. EBITDA grew +3.3% to £84.3 mn, in line with GSe and 2% below consensus at £85 mn/£86 mn. However, operating cash flow growth was stronger, +17% to £96.9 mn.

BE11:16am

What does it all mean?
Outlook: Ocado guided to capex of £175 mn vs. GSe of £158 mn in FY17E. The company also expects to continue growing faster than the online grocery market.
Cash flow: Operating cash flow +17% to £96.9 mn; this was driven by working capital improvements, which we would expect a growing food retailer to benefit from. FCF went from -£16.3 mn in FY15 to -£27 mn, reflecting increased capex.
CapEx: was £153 mn for FY16 in line with guidance of £150 mn and GSe £150 mn.
Retail gross margin: Down 49bp to 28.7% primarily due to selling price deflation.
Net Debt: Ocado had year-end net debt of £164.9 mn, c2x EBITDA. The revolving credit facility was drawn £52.5 mn, the total facility size is £210 mn and is in place to July 2019.
Market environment: Ocado pointed to input cost pressures in 2016, driven by labour cost increases and sterling devaluation, as adding to the already challenging environment and causing “margin pressure and uncertainty across the industry”.
Ocado saw basket deflation over FY16 of -2.7% to £108.10.
Non-food: Ocado’s GM product sales have grown over 40% yoy and now constitute nearly 7% of its retail sales. Ocado plans to open a second GM facility in 2018 to allow GM sales to continue growing rapidly.

BE11:16am

CFC 3 (Andover) and CFC 4 (Erith): CFC 3 commenced operations on November 25, 2016, with the company expecting volumes to increase over the coming months; it stated in this release that operations will “ramp up in future periods” and guidance of MHE capital costs of £45 mn is unchanged. CFC4 is scheduled to commence operations in FY18 with MHE capital cost guidance of £135 mn, unchanged from previous guidance.
Smart Platform: Management stated that they have “advanced discussions with multiple potential international partners to utilise the Ocado Smart Platform” No change on previous guidance of expectations to sign multiple deals in multiple territories in the medium term.
Implications
We make no changes to our £91.9 mn EBITDA estimate for 2017 However, although.
we think Bloomberg consensus of £101.8 mn needs to come down, our conversations with investors lead us to believe the market is already looking for a number closer to ours.
Given the share price has been weak, with shares -13% in the last 3m vs. European food retail average of +3% , we believe the stock will show a small positive reaction to this print.

11:17 am
PM11:17am

So it really is a belated bounce rather than Rocket

PM11:18am

I see Clive Black has moved the thing to 'under review'

BE11:18am

Oh, do share.

11:18 am
PM11:18am

Reluctantly

PM11:18am

I'll share some

PM11:18am

So, Ocado remains a business under profit pressure albeit is now in a sector where most of its store based competitors have re-based earnings. Whereas the opposition are now in a rebuilding mode, we’re not so sure that this is the case with Ocado, and so we approach issuing FY2017 financial forecasts with caution. Our central expectation is that our non-downgraded pre-Christmas 2016 estimates for EBITDA may need to be cut, noting that depreciation and amortisation are real costs for Ocado; note impairments in FY2016! Accordingly, we shall return with revised forecasts shortly, placing our present expectations under review. We also place our Hold stance on Ocado’s shares UNDER REVIEW as we weigh up whether or not a much fancied international tie-up(s) will indeed come through (and whether or not it will make any positive difference to the bottom line [do not be surprised if a whole range of technologically savvy excuses for exceptional development costs and the like follow] against what remain highly inflated valuation metrics). In truth, we really struggle with the multiples that Ocado’s shares trade on as whilst it is shopper friendly it is not so for shareholders.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Actually, I'm assuming that he's minded to become a reluctant buyer

PM11:19am

But maybe not.

PM11:19am

CUrrent Shore recommendation is Hold

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Hm. The simple fact is that Ocado's running at 20% order growth and still not turning anything close to a decent profit.

BE11:21am

It can keep running at 20% order growth and that'll require building more warehouses (something it warns explicitly about in today's statement ....

BE11:22am

.... as in, capex of £175m next year. Consensus is for £135m I believe. Warehouses are expensive!)

11:22 am
PM11:22am

Sure are

BE11:22am

Or it can stop growing and rerate to be a normal supermarket with a 1% market share and much lower than average margins, so ....... 10x earnings?

BE11:23am

Or! it can sign this damn international deal and become a tech stock.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

One day! Maybe.

BE11:23am

Morgan Stanley .......

BE11:23am

Overall, Ocado reported a set of in-line numbers for FY16, which is reassuring given downbeat expectations and a relatively weak performance of the shares recently. Of note, Ocado's efficiency metrics (fulfilment centre productivity, deliveries per van, throughput capacity, etc.) have continued to improve even in its mature fulfillment centres. Ocado says in the release it expects its capex to increase in FY17 but for a company currently in the process of doubling its sales capacity and further improving the efficiency of its current operations, this does not derail the bulls' arguments we believe. Having spoken with the company though, we expect the market in FY17 to competitive, and gross margin pressures to remain acute, which we think could lead consensus to adjust around the mid-£90m level for FY17's EBITDA. This is already where most recent estimates stand but would be lower than current consensus at ~£100m.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

And Bernstein.

BE11:24am

The key miss is in the top line: profitability is falling even before switch on of Andover. The later switching on of Andover means market & us over estimated its impact on D&A in H2, but that is simply a delay. EBITDA missing before we get full impact of the new CFC reducing efficiency means we can expect management to guide down profitability expectations for next year.

BE11:24am

Material Capex step-up for 2017 to £175m, up from £153m this year and 54% above our expectation of £114m. It's unclear at this stage what is driving the big increase in capex but we hope to understand more at the analyst call. Ocado capitalises a lot of it IT costs but there is a grey zone in our view between operating expenses and capex.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

Group operating profit before exceptionals & JVs of £21.9m; 4.0% above consensus of £21.1m and 27.1% above our expectation of £17.2m. All this is driven by a delayed Andover opening. Diluted EPS of 1.96p; 14% ahead of consensus of 1.72p and 15% above our expectation of 1.70p, again driven by a delayed Andover opening.

Year-end statutory net debt £164.9m ; 6% below expectation of 174.5m. Year-end cash position was kept at £50.9m by drawing down £52.5m on the credit facility.

Mature CFC UPH 160 and DPV 176 this is in line with our expectations of 160 UPH and 175 DPV for the full year. On time delivery has remained steady in line with H1 at 94.9% and order accuracy has fallen slightly in H2 to 98.9% compared to 99.1% in H1.

Get ready for EBITDA expectations to come down for 2017.

BE11:25am

Bruno's a seller. Started coverage last week, I think. Excellent note. Seek it out.

11:27 am
IG Group Holdings PLC (IGG:LSE): Last: 525.50, down 21.5 (-3.93%), High: 544.00, Low: 522.00, Volume: 1.30m
PM11:27am

What's he saying?

BE11:27am

Partly a "tough trading" argument .... Plus a bit of regulatory change stuff that's interesting.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

... in the sense that the argument is "we don't bloody know and neither do you: optimism isn't an investment strategy"

BE11:28am

(That's me paraphrasing.)

BE11:28am

Here's the gist of it.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

While our FY17E forecasts are broadly unchanged, we reduce our FY18E/19E EPS forecasts by 20%/12% mainly because we bring revenue/client down again, particularly in the UK (we still, however, forecast client growth, even in the UK). Thus, this remains a risk: should IG experience a contraction in the number of clients, the risk for our forecasts remains to the downside. It is our opinion that IG will be able to offset some of the anticipated revenue decline with cost reductions, and after growing underlying operating expenses by £32MM, or 13%, in FY17, we forecast underlying operating expenses to decrease by 5% in FY18, and then fall another 5% in FY19.

BE11:29am

We do not believe that further analysing the pending regulatory change will provide any additional clarity. Unfortunately, this overhang will likely persist as (1) the final regulations are announced (spring 2017), (2) the regulations become effective (likely summer 2017), (3) IG reworks its product offering, and revenue and profits decline (H1/FY18), (4) financial performance stabilisation occurs (H2/FY18 at the earliest), (5) a financial recovery occurs (FY19 at the earliest). In addition, it is likely in our opinion that further adverse regulatory measures will be implemented in some of IG’s other operating geographies.

BE11:29am

Price target increased 2% to 510p on higher valuation multiple. We still believe that a discount to IG’s historical forward trading multiple is warranted to reflect impaired earnings visibility and the potential for further adverse regulatory change. However, it is now our opinion that our FY18 forecasts are in the right ballpark (we still have low conviction in our FY19 forecasts), and thus we increase IG’s valuation multiple to 12x from 10x. We believe that a multiple between our previous valuation multiple (10x) and IG’s longer-term forward P/E multiple (15x) is now appropriate. We continue to incorporate surplus capital in our valuation.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

The key reason we downgrade IG to Underperform is because our 510p price target is below the current share price, despite assigning IG a valuation multiple 20% higher than our previous multiple. We believe that the current share price has yet to fully reflect the numerous challenges the business will encounter. Our Underperform rating is based upon (i) regulation contagion to other geographies is likely, (ii) client contraction is possible, yet we do not forecast it, (iii) the dividend policy could be maintained, which would result in a dividend cut, and (iv) financial performance stabilisation and recovery could take longer than we envision.

BE11:29am

....... all of which looks fair enough.

BE11:30am

And needs to be seen, perhaps, in the perspective of IG being one of the better operators in the sector.

11:00 am
PM11:01am

BE11:32am

We utilise a 12x multiple to value IG, to reflect sector derating (which we believe is warranted) following the FCA announcement. In addition, we incorporate IG’s surplus capital in our valuation, utilising our end of FY17 surplus capital estimate of 22p per share. The multiple that we use to value IG is a two-turn valuation premium to the multiple we apply to IG's closest peer (CMC Markets).

BE11:32am

(I don't know what a two-turn valuation premium is. Perhaps you can help, ROTR.)

11:32 am

undefined
BE11:33am

While on the bookies -- which is what IG is, let's face it ......

11:33 am
BE11:33am

... we have FOBT news today, of sorts.

BE11:33am

Or at least a lot of noise.

BE11:33am

The Fixed Odds Betting Terminals APPG has its report filed, exactly on deadline.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

http://www.fobt-appg.com/latest-news/

BE11:34am

The findings of the report include

That there is now a ‘prima facie’ case for significantly reducing the maximum stake that can be wagered on a FOBT
At the very least the stake should be reduced on a precautionary basis, in line with the principles which govern the work of the Gambling Commission, until sufficient evidence is presented to the Government that the high stakes on these machines do not cause harm
That the Gambling Commission “have failed” to adequately advise the Government in recent years, despite the principles for regulation and licencing under which the Gambling Commission operates
That there is a case for the maximum stake to be reduced to £2
Government should also consider reducing the speed of spin on a FOBT in order to reduce the potential for harm to be caused and also review the number of FOBTs permitted in an individual bookmaker
Government should address localism concerns and calls for greater controls over FOBTs at the local level. Powers should be given to local authorities to prevent the clustering of betting shops.

BE11:35am

And, inevitably, the bookmakers are screaming foul play at anyone who'll listen.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

The Association of British Bookmakers (ABB) warned of thousands of job losses and bookmaker closures if the study's recommendations were implemented.

Its chief executive, Malcolm George, said: "The report is the view of a tiny group of anti-betting shop MPs.

"This group has been financed by those with interests in the casino, arcade and pub industries. We strongly believe that the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards should urgently investigate this All-Party Parliamentary Group.

"This group of MPs has operated in secrecy, provided no transcripts of the evidence given to their meetings and operated throughout behind closed doors away from public scrutiny.

"Britain's bookmakers employ more than 43,000 staff and contribute over £1bn a year in taxes.

"But, betting shops are already closing at the rate of more than 100 a year and if the findings of this rigged report are implemented, it could spell the beginning of the end for the High Street bookmaker."

BE11:36am

http://news.sky.co...ookmakers-10749628

PM11:36am

Goodness

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Anyway, all the bookies sold off this morning because it seems the people who manage your pension don't know the difference between a government review and an all-party parliamentary committee.

BE11:37am

That mistake has now been pointed out to them and the sector has rallied. But volume's about ten times the average already.

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 260.00, up 0.5 (+0.19%), High: 262.70, Low: 253.20, Volume: 7.29m
11:38 am
Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 119.80, up 0.4 (+0.34%), High: 120.30, Low: 115.60, Volume: 2.91m
BE11:38am

BE11:38am

Here's Davy.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

The report’s findings were leaked last December and, as such, it should contain little new. It is important to stress that this report is essentially just one submission to the official government triennial review of gaming machines which is now expected to release its findings by May. It is that report which will be binding, not this one.

BE11:39am

While the calls for a £2 staking limit worry shareholders in
William Hill and Ladbrokes Coral, we believe that such an
outcome is quite unlikely. Apart from the fact that it would
seriously impact the industry, it seems to us that there is little
direct evidence linking FOBTs with a greater propensity to
problem gambling. We do think that the maximum stake is
likely to be reduced but that the change will be more moderate.
At worst, we think that a £20 staking limit might be applied.

BE11:39am

Davy notes that Hill and Ladbrokes were down 6% and 9% respectively when this leaked in December.

BE11:57am

PM11:57am

PM11:57am

On this inflation surge

PM11:57am

But I don't think anyone thinks there's gonig to be a sudden reaction fromthe ECB

PM11:58am

PM11:58am

Here's Citi

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Euro area inflation surged to a 4-year high of 1.8% YY in Jan – up from 1.1% in Dec-16 and 0.2% on average in 2016 and well above consensus (of 1.5%; Citi: 1.7%). Higher energy inflation (8.1% from 2.6% in Dec and -1.1% in Nov) and fresh food price inflation (3.3% from 2.1% YY in Dec and 0.7% in Nov) drove the headline rate higher. Both effects are unlikely to be reversed in the next few months, in our view.
Core inflation remains contained, for now – Ex-food, energy and tobacco HICP was stable at 0.9% YY in Jan, still in line with the 2016 average, albeit slightly higher than the H2 16 average of 0.8%. Services HICP inflation eased to 1.2% YY from 1.3% YY in Dec, while non-energy goods HICP picked up from 0.3%YY to 0.5%, possibly reflecting a weaker currency and higher commodity prices (although in part possibly also MM seasonal volatility, usually high in January).

PM11:58am

Headline inflation to rise further in the next couple of months – to probably 2%, and to subside only slightly below 2% for the remainder of the year. Core inflation is likely to remain much more subdued, but we think it may start creeping higher throughout 2017 on narrowing spare capacity, indirect effects of higher commodity prices and fading effects of the euro appreciation. While headline inflation may eventually converge back to core in 2018 (to around 1.4%), the large and positive headline-core gap, for the first time since 2012, is likely to ‘pull’ core somewhat higher over the coming months (see Fig 1).
GDP accelerated to 0.5% QQ in 4Q 16 – as expected, up from 0.4% QQ in 3Q (revised higher from 0.3%) and 0.3% in 2Q. The YY rate was stable at 1.8%. The acceleration is line with improvements in surveys since Sep-16 and the January surveys point to 1Q 17 growth likely to remain at least as strong as in 4Q 16. 2016 average GDP growth (at 1.7%) was for the second consecutive year probably above potential (of ~1 ¼%), implying further narrowing of the output gap.

PM11:58am

Unemployment rate dropped to 9.6% in Dec-16 – down from a downward-revised 9.7% in Nov and lowest since mid-2009, in yet another sign of diminishing spare capacity (also signalled by the rising capacity utilization rates, see Fig 2). On current trends, the euro area jobless rate will be back to pre-crisis lows in 2019.
ECB unlikely to react any time soon to the improved macro picture – although headline inflation is likely to move close to target in the next few months, core remains well below this level. This will still be the key to determine the ECB medium-term inflation outlook. We think the bar for the ECB to modify its Dec-16 decisions on monetary policy stimulus for 2017 is quite high – as confirmed by the Austrian governor Nowotny yesterday. Yet, increasing signs of narrowing spare capacity and higher headline inflation will likely spur further tensions within the ECB Governing Council.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

Done

BE11:59am

There's also a Credit Suisse thing around, raising Euro Stoxx 50 mid-year targets

BE12:00pm

Garthwaite, of course. I'm sure it can reach the usual place some time today, but here are the bullet points.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

 Continental Europe: stick to this being our joint top overweight. We raise our year-end Euro Stoxx 50 target to 3,450 from 3,300 (and midyear target to 3,500 from 3,350). What is supportive?

 There has been significant capitulation.

 GDP growth of 2% should be consistent with c.15% outperformance.

 The stage of the cycle: Europe outperforms 70% of the time the bund yield rises and also outperforms when the global cycle turns up.

 Valuation: Europe's 12-month forward P/E is on a 19% discount to the US, and a 17% discount on normalised earnings. The equity risk premium is still high, at 7.4%.

 Profits: earnings momentum in absolute and relative terms is at a 5-year high. We upgrade EPS growth to 8.5% for 2017 (from c.6%). Nearly half of consensus EPS growth is from financials and energy (where we have net upgrades in both).

Rising inflation helps margins. Above all, the profit share of GDP remains close to trough levels.

 The ECB is likely to remain dovish until at least the aftermath of the French elections.

 What usually goes wrong or has gone wrong in the past, and why are we sanguine about these risks?

 Strong growth leads to a strong euro. However, this time around ECB QE leads to a depressed Bund yield, driving bond portfolio outflows and keeping the euro weak;

 GEM - Europe is the most exposed region to GEM (outside of GEM itself). However, we are a small overweight of GEM and European GEM exposure has lagged GEM direct exposure;

 Europe does not own much disruptive technology. However, disruptive technology being long duration tends to underperform when bond yields rise;

 Political risk. However, we believe this is overstated in the 2017 - especially if Fillon becomes President. What do we buy?

 We continue to buy plays on European domestic demand (SAP, Adecco, Randstad, Atos, WPP) and banks and life companies (though preferring life companies to banks).
